reviewText:
Final Slam 2 is, to put it quite frankly, an abomination of a game. It falls below poorly designed shovelware into something that feels like an insult to other games in the genre. As a fighting game it fails on a fundamental level with a horribly shallow pool of moves, awful controls (which includes a complete lack of gamepad support), and broken systems that make fights feel entirely reliant on luck. Every aspect of the game, from the tutorial to simply the menu navigation, manages to be far more convoluted and confusing than it should ever be, making something as simple as changing the screen resolution unintuitive.

The art design has the dubious honor of being possibly the worst of any retail game I've yet seen, with horrendous character designs, blurry textures, an inadmissible lack of detail in every scene, and horrendous animations that can hardly be called as such. It's like MS Paint got exceedingly drunk, and this is the aftermath that it threw up the next morning. The over the top and misogynistic dialog from the story mode is just the last nail in a terribly constructed coffin.

If it was possibly to revoke my copy of Final Slam 2, I'd gladly take the chance to never have to glance at it again in my library. It's one of the worst games I've had the displeasure of playing on Steam, and I shudder to think that people are actually paying for something that would compare unfavorably to the average flash game. Please, for your own protection, do not partake in playing this game, it will give you nothing back and devour any last hope that there is still some quality control on this platform.
voteText: 21 of 24 people (88%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I don't like putting the thumbs down but it forces you to choose one or the other, it pains me to do it because I understand the work that must have gone in to this but I can't give it a thumbs up.

This game needs a lot of work, it's not half as smooth as a fighting game demands.
It's a very ambitious game and you get the feeling the devs are focusing more on grandiose atmosphere rather than fluid gameplay.
No controller support, this is vital, it felt awkward as all hell on keyboard, especially with the clunky moves and hit boxes the flash engine brings, other titles like Castle Crashers have done brilliantly in transitioning from flash to steam, this game just doesn't do it right.

I do see what they're going for, I like the overall idea, it's just executed in a way that makes it hard to play.

I hope I can turn that thumb around some day.

reviewText:
Final Slam II is a fighting game originally made in Flash. And as a Newgrounds submission Final Slam II is pretty decent, but unfortunately it doesn't hold up compared to other independently developed fighting games, especially those released on Steam. Final Slam II goes for the simple with it comes to combat. You use WASD and GHJ (no gamepad support which is typical for Flash games) to control your fighter but the way fighters move, jump and punch seems very much unnatural, like a combination of the original Street Fighter and the original Virtua Fighter. As to be expected there is a story mode (a cliched and confusing one) in addition to a tournament mode.

The best thing that Final Slam II has going for it is the character creation system. Using a large variety of body parts, colors and a few sizes you can create your own fighter with special moves, stances, poses, and voice chosen by you. Unfortunately this is also one of the game's biggest flaws because all the characters already in the game were created this way, and use the same custom mannequin" creation method. There's no expression or animation outside the movement and rotation of body parts and it gives you this strange feeling that you're playing with jointed paper dolls instead of martial arts masters. On top of this is the fact that the only difference between male and female fighters is the large set of boobs pasted onto the male torso.

I've played a lot of fighting games in my lifetime from Street Fighter
date: most games on the Neo Geo and Skullgirls to more obscure titles like Yatagarasu and MONSTER and in my opinion the quality of this game does not merit the price. If you want to try the game for yourself before paying
recommended: you need only head to Newgrounds and play Final Slam II there for free. The only real difference between the paid version on Steam and the free version is the full Story mode
hoursPlayed: a Season mode and more custom fighter slots.\n\nYou can find much better fighting games on Steam. Not recommended."

reviewText:
There are only two things I really liked about this game

+ The Create A Wrestler system is actually pretty cool, some diversity in the 'ring gear' and the moves were kinda nice. I say this because for me, who loved to spend hours in the Create Mode in every WWE game, I really enjoyed creating my own aberration.

+ The trading cards, who doesn't love money, right?


I might save some good words for the soundtrack as well, but everything else in this game is crap, the fighting system is AWFUL, just spam a button and you win, or lose, because the AI can SPAM THE SAME THING.

The combos don't work AT ALL and I actually had some fun by just stunning every opponent and yelling STONE COLD STONE COLD STONE COLD.

What a shame, I really, reaaally liked the create a wrestler mode, well, get your trading cards and stay the hell away from this garbage.

reviewText:
Final Slam 2 is a simple 2D fighter with not much going on to it. I haven't played it much, but i'll try to give it the best review I can.

The characters and animations looks rediculous. The animations skips all the time and are super buggy, the graphic settings are very poor: ( Music: High/Low/Mute, Volume: High/Low/Mute, Quality: Best/Good/Low and Resolution: Windowed/Wide/Full. ) Also the A.I. is pretty badly designed, either it spams stuff at you or lets you kill him. This game is available for free with less content on a popular Flash Games website and it only got about 25,000 views compared to tons of other games with 10,000,000+ views.

The tutorial is a bunch of text that you need to click ''Next'' in order progress through it. The Steam overlay dosen't even work in game, you cannot take screenshots, this game features no achievements... All it has available is Single-player or Local Co-Op. The best part of the game is the fighter creator: While the UI and general appearance is still quite basic, it does have alot more customization options than in many games. At least you get Steam Cards as a reward for playing this game!

All in all, the game UI is terrible, the gameplay is not fluid and there's no multiplayer. In it's current state, this game should be free and I cannot recommend purchasing it.

reviewText: I honestly enjoyed this game, in the same way I enjoyed the fighting games on the SNES and PS1 back in the day, both by the big companies and the upstarts trying to copy and tweak the formula.   Yes, it's got relatively poor graphics but it controls just fine (I'd prefer that a controller option worked but the keyboard is servicable, for once), the story mode lasted me well over an hour (it's cheesy and ridiculous, but fun and really long for a fighting game), and there's a ton of customization and random match options.  Overall I'm glad to have tried it.  It's not a game for everyone obviously but it deserves more praise than vitriol.

reviewText:
Genre: Casual 2D Traditional Fighting Game

Summary:
Final Slam 2 is a simplistic 3-button fighting game in the vein of Mortal Kombat-style footsies (emphasis on special attacks).
The system mechanics include MK-style special inputs, an auto-dodge while blocking (occurs based on the amount of health), and taunting to heal health.

Pros:
- The character customization, in regards to appearances, allows for a lot of user input with it's variety of options.
- It's possible to script the A.I. in a detailed manner.
- The tutorial is brief and concise.

Cons:
- Elements such as auto-dodge and mashing for speed attacks detracts from strategic play.
- No arcade stick or controller support.
- No training mode
- There a down throw as opposed to a back throw.
- The character designs are generic, blocky, and well, ugly.
- Every character feels like they use one of three move sets.
- Animations are choppy due to the game's low frame rate.
- The stages are bland.
- The voice clips are generic.
- Being able to customize attack SFX is a bad idea, since fighting game players use them as cues.
- The attack and taunt animations are all boring.

Neutral Points:
- The music is alright, but it's also not very memorable.
- Simulation mode is pointless unless you're really bored; nobody wants to watch CPU's fight.
- There's an option that makes K.O.'s unavailable unless a special attack finishes the opponent. This waters down the game but at least it's optional.
- Cutscenes consist of text dialogue with a character sprite.
- Customizable character can select any stance for their fighting style, which is bad idea, but hardly matters since this isn't a competitive game.
- No online, but that's fine considering the quality of this game.
- You can select a faction to fight for in versus mode, which doesn't add to anything.

Personal Opinion:
This is a fighting game targeted at casual gamers. Regardless of that fact, this game is shoddy and lacks a lot of polish and originality.

reviewText:
Mortal Kombat 1 meets The Room the movie and early South Park.

A horribly, horribly funny game, plenty amusing.

Success in story mode = make all punches to the groin (or ballet or twirling to it, or whatelse the specific character's doing to the oponent's lower lower ab area). Game mechanics are unbalanced, look hilariously ugly and it all plays bad.

The score is a masterpiece of camp.

The game is horrible yet I enjoyed it for just that.

reviewText:
Allright m8s! Let's write the first Possitive Review for Final Slam 2!

Okay, as a lot of you, I got it for free. I've seen a lot of bad, negative reviews about this game, so here's mine:

It is a nice game in my opinion, my favorite thing about Final Slam 2 is the Character Creator, it does features a lot of movements, taunts, clothes, anything you might need to make your own fighter!

Pros

--> Character Creator
--> Music
--> Classic Fighting game play style
--> It does has Trading Cards

Cons

--> The Art Style (Sorry, but I don't like it)
--> You can't use your Own Character to play (Except if you are in the Simulation Mode)
--> Is it a Flash Game?
--> Well... Now 9.99$ is an Expensive Price

I still haven't take a look into the Story of this game. But as far I've seen, it is a 2 chapters Story about a Fighter called Turner.

6/10 Could be better.
Ign Approved Review~

reviewText:
The Japanese have a term for very subpar video games; Kusoge. The '-ge' meaning 'game' and the kuso-' literally meaning '‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•' or '‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•'. I actually rather like kusoge, finding a strange joy in seeing how hilariously bad games can be

Final Slam 2 is not kusoge. Final Slam 2 is a game so lacking in quality and entertainment, that even after I made a character who leaps into battle with no pants and has a command list made entirely of head butts, and taunts by slapping his backside, I still failed to have any fun with this game

This is the Star Wars Holiday Special of fighting games; watching that movie, or playing this game will make you feel equally dirty

reviewText: Usually don't post reviews but I can't help it. I got this game for free with admittedly high expectations as I had gotten like 3 really good free games in a row. In theory it sounded great. Simple fighting game with a story and full character customization with 80 whole spots to save them in. Well ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.\n\nFirst thing is the character customization and everything else looks like crap. All of it. Which is very disappointing because I love making custom characters. I don't doubt that somebody tried, it has a ton of options, but knowing your game looks like that why would you think that I would make 80 characters? And girl fighters are out of the question, they look like dudes regardless of choosing female". Probably why they showed the character creator running at the speed of light in the tutorial. Alright fine

recommended: all of these moves look horribly unnatural. Whatever
